data.name: JVM
data.description: View of key metrics relating to the health and performance of Java Virtual machine.

markdown.markdownText:
**JVM**

The Java Virtual Machine (JVM)is the runtime environment that enables Java applications to execute. JVMs are widely used across a range of applications, from web services to enterprise software, making it essential to monitor their performance and resource usage to ensure smooth operations. Proper JVM monitoring helps in identifying performance bottlenecks, optimizing resource utilization, and preventing potential issues that can impact application stability and responsiveness.

This dashboard is part of the out-of-box extension and provides visibility to and alerting on key performance metrics.

**Use Cases Covered**

* Memory
* CPU
* Garbage Collection
* Threads
* JVM Classes
* Buffers & Codes
    **More about performance monitoring of JVM workload** [ here](https://opentelemetry.io/docs/specs/semconv/runtime/jvm-metrics/)

# Memory - Heap/Non-Heap
1.  Allocation Efficiency - used / committed - Allocation efficiency looks at how much of the committed memory is actually in use. 
2. OutOfMemoryError - used / limit - How close you are to the max allowed memory for that pool. 
3. After GC Baseline Usage - (memory usage after last gc / limit or committed) - Evaluates GC effectiveness at freeing space. A consistently high baseline after GC (>80–90%) suggests long-lived object retention or potential memory leaks, increasing the risk of OutOfMemoryError.

* **Heap/Non-Heap Memory Thresholds:**
    * 0% - 70% → 🟢 Normal
    * 70% - 90% → 🟠 Warning
    * Above 90% → 🔴 Critical

**Note: Threshold values are configurable.**

widgets.title: JVM Heap Memory Used (%) Per Pool -  Allocation Efficiency
widgets.description: How much of the allocated (committed) memory is actually in use.

widgets.title: JVM Heap Memory Used (%) Per Pool - OutOfMemoryError
widgets.description: How close you are to the max allowed memory for that pool.

widgets.title: JVM Heap Memory Used (%) - WRT Max Memory
widgets.description: How close you are to the max allowed memory for that pool.

promqlQuery.value: (100 * avg(process_runtime_jvm_memory_usage_By{ type="heap",service_name=~"{{service_name}}",host_name=~"{{host_name}}",pool=~"{{pool}}",host_id=~"{{host_id}}"}) by (service_name,host_name)/ avg(process_runtime_jvm_memory_limit_By{ type="heap",service_name=~"{{service_name}}",host_name=~"{{host_name}}",pool=~"{{pool}}",host_id=~"{{host_id}}"}) by (service_name,host_name)) or on() vector(0)

widgets.title: Current JVM Heap Memory Used (%) - WRT Max Memory
widgets.description: How close you are to the max allowed memory for that pool.

widgets.title: Top Hosts With High Heap Memory Used (%) - WRT Max Memory
widgets.description: How close you are to the max allowed memory for that pool.

widgets.title: JVM Non-Heap Memory Used (%) - WRT Max Memory
widgets.description: How close you are to the max allowed memory for that pool.

promqlQuery.value: (100 * avg(process_runtime_jvm_memory_usage_By{ type="non_heap",service_name=~"{{service_name}}",host_name=~"{{host_name}}",pool=~"{{pool}}",host_id=~"{{host_id}}"}) by (service_name,host_name)/ avg(process_runtime_jvm_memory_limit_By{ type="non_heap",service_name=~"{{service_name}}",host_name=~"{{host_name}}",pool=~"{{pool}}",host_id=~"{{host_id}}"}) by (service_name,host_name)) or on() vector(0)

widgets.title: JVM Non-Heap Memory Used (%) - WRT Max Memory
widgets.description: How close you are to the max allowed memory for that pool.

widgets.title: Heap % After GC - OutOfMemoryError
widgets.description: Displays the percentage of heap memory still in use immediately after the most recent garbage collection, relative to the JVM’s maximum heap size.

widgets.title: Heap % After GC - Allocation Efficiency
widgets.description: Shows the percentage of committed heap memory still in use immediately after the most recent garbage collection.

widgets.title: JVM Heap Memory Used (%) -  Allocation Efficiency
widgets.description: How much of the allocated (committed) memory is actually in use.

promqlQuery.value: (100 * avg(process_runtime_jvm_memory_usage_By{ type="heap",service_name=~"{{service_name}}",host_name=~"{{host_name}}",pool=~"{{pool}}",host_id=~"{{host_id}}"}) by (service_name,host_name)/ avg(process_runtime_jvm_memory_committed_By{ type="heap",service_name=~"{{service_name}}",host_name=~"{{host_name}}",pool=~"{{pool}}",host_id=~"{{host_id}}"}) by (service_name,host_name)) or on() vector(0)

widgets.title: JVM Non-Heap Memory Used (%) -  Allocation Efficiency
widgets.description: How much of the allocated (committed) memory is actually in use.

markdown.markdownText:
# CPU 
1. JVM CPU Utilization -  Fraction of CPU capacity used by the JVM process. High values mean the JVM is consuming significant CPU.

* **CPU Thresholds:**
    * 0% - 70% → 🟢 Normal
    * 70% - 90% → 🟠 Warning
    * Above 90% → 🔴 Critical

**Note: Threshold values are configurable.**

widgets.title: Top Hosts With High CPU Used (%)

markdown.markdownText:
# GC - Garbage Collection
1. GC Pause Efficiency (GC Duration) - Average time spent per garbage collection event. Short pauses = healthy GC; long pauses = possible tuning/memory issues. 
2. Time Pressure -  Percentage of total CPU time spent performing garbage collection.

widgets.title: Average GC Pause Efficiency
widgets.description: What it means: Average time spent per garbage collection event.  Purpose: Measures how efficient each GC cycle is at reclaiming memory without long pauses. Short, stable pause durations indicate healthy GC behavior; longer or erratic pauses may signal memory pressure or suboptimal GC tuning.

widgets.title: Average GC Pause Efficiency  - By Action

markdown.markdownText:
# Threads – JVM
1. Live Threads -  Total number of live JVM threads (daemon + non-daemon). Indicates current thread activity.
2. Daemon Threads - Number of JVM daemon threads. Useful for monitoring background activity and resource usage.
3. Peak Threads - Highest number of live threads observed since JVM start. Helps spot thread spikes and capacity issues. 
4. Threads by State - Breakdown of threads by state (RUNNABLE, WAITING, TIMED_WAITING, BLOCKED). Identifies contention, waiting patterns, and potential deadlocks.

widgets.title: Daemon Threads
widgets.description: Number of JVM daemon threads. Useful for monitoring background activity and resource usage.

widgets.title: Peak Threads
widgets.description: ighest number of live threads observed since JVM start. Helps spot thread spikes and capacity issues.

widgets.title: JVM Threads by State
widgets.description: Breakdown of threads by state (RUNNABLE, WAITING, TIMED_WAITING, BLOCKED). Identifies contention, waiting patterns, and potential deadlocks.

widgets.title: JVM Threads by State Per Host

markdown.markdownText:
# JVM Classes
1. Loaded Classes - Shows the current number of Java classes loaded in the JVM. 
2. Unloaded Classes - Shows the total number of Java classes unloaded since the JVM started. Healthy JVMs unload unused classes over time; a very low value alongside rising loaded classes may suggest a classloader leak.

# Bufferes & Code 
1. Buffer Memory Used - Bytes of memory currently used by JVM buffers (direct and mapped). Sudden growth may indicate excessive direct buffer allocation. 
2. Code Usage - Bytes of JVM code cache in use. High or full code cache usage can trigger OutOfMemoryError: CodeCache is full and cause JIT compilation to stop.
